That's actually super smart. So, he races enough money. Since it costs 1% to ensure the trade, he pays that one percent. Instead of raising just the amount that he needs to make the train call Ma he raises the amount that he needs given his current risk appetite: so, if he wants to that against $12 billion worth of funds, he will be losing $12 million a year. To stomach that, he needs a fund where is investors are fine losing 12%. However, since savings accounts have rates of 5%, as long as we can put the money into a savings account, we earn 5 percent. So, while he loses 12% and earns 5%, his actual loss is only 7%. On top of that, if he takes a one percent fee, that means it’s 8%, and if he knows that investors will leave him if his losses drop to more than 25%, he can get away with 3 years of insurance taking this 1% management fee. Now you calculate how much you need to raise: at 12% annual losses (they can stomach 8%-1% of that 8 comes from your fee+5% that you get back in treasuries) and 1% paid in annual insurance, that means you can buy capital_raised*12%/1%=12 times the amount of capital raised. So, if you raise $1B, you can buy insurance on $12B in mortgages
